history.content:
Hi --

We're looking for an enthusiastic, undergraduate student to help in a project, related to safety for patients in MRI.   Any electrical cable used inside an MRI machine can interact with the MRI transmitter and can be an RF burn safety risk  to the patients in the scanner. Examples, are transmission lines for MRI coils, or power / data cables for peripherals. Unfortunately it is not possible to use Ferrite Cores to block these currents  as they are magnetic and can not be placed in the strong magnetic field of the MRI system. Current solutions in industry use.

In our project, which is a collaboration with GE healthcare, we are designing  resonant, distributed devices that block unwanted currents on cables inside an MRI machine, to prevent Radio frequency burns to the patient. 

We are looking for "handy" candidates, who are not afraid to build and test devices (even on a real-large size MRI machine)

Experience in CAD design, 3D printing is advantageous.

Experience in RF and electrical measurements is also a plus.

Please contact Miki Lustig mikilustig@berkeley.edu  or Ekin Karasan ekin_karasan@berkeley.edu . Make sure you use [RF TRAP Project]  in your subject. 

--  Miki
history.subject: Looking for keen undergrad researchers for an MRI instrumentation project
